biography.value:
Backstory

Father: Gnome Bard, traveling from place to place and fickle in love. Duped her orc mother and ran away after fooling around and getting a new tale for his collection. Mother: Orc Druid. Probably shouldn’t be a ‘murder murder murder’ orc because she slept with a gnome.  Backstory: Character was looked down upon for her smaller stature and strange (gnomish) facial features. (She hates her ears).  Has overcome the size difference between herself and the other orcs with sheer rage. After her coming of age, she realized she will never be valued by the tribe. Even when she showed her strength and her value with tinkering (with comparatively tiny sausage fingers she can probably make little crafty thingamadoozers?), the tribe still looked down upon her. Realizing her daughter’s hardship, her mother gives her an heirloom (????? Something he left behind? Dagger? Instrument? Whatever bards carry). Despite being left by the swindler gnome after a few nights of honeyed words and passion, mama orc cannot forget him. Character has a different motivation for leaving the tribe: revenge. Not as foolhardy as her mother, she blames him for what she has endured due to her small stature. Now she seeks someone to track the owner of the heirloom. Tracking via spell? Spells aren’t cheap, so she has left her tribe and turned to adventuring. She is naive, but not stupid. Impulsive and short sighted. Motto: “Always forward!” Turn left or turn right? Go through the woods and blaze your own trail! Climb the mountain, burst through the wall, whatever it is, always forward. (Hold “W” to win shotgun ape) You can expand on details of your friend and how they caught you, maybe your raiders squad got raided? Orcs come from the "Savage Frontier." Entrepreneurial parties often come to turn the tides between the tribes. Your mother could have probably healed your friend with some kind of regeneration, you don't know, you're not a druid. but many of her instruments were taken in the raid?
biography.public:
Backstory

Father: Gnome Bard, traveling from place to place and fickle in love. Duped her orc mother and ran away after fooling around and getting a new tale for his collection. Mother: Orc Druid. Probably shouldn’t be a ‘murder murder murder’ orc because she slept with a gnome.  Backstory: Character was looked down upon for her smaller stature and strange (gnomish) facial features. (She hates her ears).  Has overcome the size difference between herself and the other orcs with sheer rage. After her coming of age, she realized she will never be valued by the tribe. Even when she showed her strength and her value with tinkering (with comparatively tiny sausage fingers she can probably make little crafty thingamadoozers?), the tribe still looked down upon her. Realizing her daughter’s hardship, her mother gives her an heirloom (????? Something he left behind? Dagger? Instrument? Whatever bards carry). Despite being left by the swindler gnome after a few nights of honeyed words and passion, mama orc cannot forget him. Character has a different motivation for leaving the tribe: revenge. Not as foolhardy as her mother, she blames him for what she has endured due to her small stature. Now she seeks someone to track the owner of the heirloom. Tracking via spell? Spells aren’t cheap, so she has left her tribe and turned to adventuring. She is naive, but not stupid. Impulsive and short sighted. Motto: “Always forward!” Turn left or turn right? Go through the woods and blaze your own trail! Climb the mountain, burst through the wall, whatever it is, always forward. (Hold “W” to win shotgun ape) You can expand on details of your friend and how they caught you, maybe your raiders squad got raided? Orcs come from the "Savage Frontier." Entrepreneurial parties often come to turn the tides between the tribes. Your mother could have probably healed your friend with some kind of regeneration, you don't know, you're not a druid. but many of her instruments were taken in the raid?

details.ideal:
Live and Let Live. Ideals aren’t worth killing over or going to war for. (Neutral)
Live and Let Live. Ideals aren’t worth killing over or going to war for. (Neutral)
details.bond:
I’ll never forget the crushing defeat my company suffered or the enemies who dealt it.
Someone saved my life on the battlefield. To this day, I will never leave a friend behind.
details.flaw:
My hatred of my enemies is blind and unreasoning.
I have little respect for anyone who is not a proven warrior.
My hatred of my enemies is blind and unreasoning.
details.appearance:
Gender: Female
Eyes: Gold
Height: 4'2"
Hair: Brown
Skin: Green

details.trait:
I can stare down a hell hound without flinching.
I face problems head-on. A simple, direct solution is the best path to success.

description.value:
Description

A fierce warrior who can enter a battle rage

Hit Die: d12
Primary Ability: Strength
Saves: Strength & Constitution 

Class Features

Level 1: Hit Points

Hit Dice: 1d12 per barbarian level
Hit Points at 1st Level: 12 + your Constitution modifier
Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d12 (or 7) + your Constitution modifier per barbarian level after 1st

Level 1: Proficiencies

Armor: Light armor, medium armor, shields
Weapons: Simple weapons, martial weapons
Tools: None
Saving Throws: Strength, Constitution
Skills: Choose two from &Reference[ani]{Animal Handling}, &Reference[ath]{Athletics}, &Reference[itm]{Intimidation}, &Reference[nat]{Nature}, &Reference[prc]{Perception}, and &Reference[sur]{Survival}

Level 1: Equipment

You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background:

  • (a) a greataxe or (b) any martial melee weapon
  • (a) two handaxes or (b) any simple weapon
  • An explorer’s pack and four javelins

@UUID[Compendium.world.ddb-hoard-of-the-dragon-queen-ddb-classes.Item.ymNjbJm2yQLHizvT]{Level 1: Rage}

In battle, you fight with primal ferocity. On your turn, you can enter a rage as a bonus action.

While raging, you gain the following benefits if you aren’t wearing heavy armor:

  • You have advantage on Strength checks and Strength saving throws.
  • When you make a melee weapon attack using Strength, you gain a bonus to the damage roll that increases as you gain levels as a barbarian, as shown in the Rage Damage column of the Barbarian table.
  • You have resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage.

If you are able to cast spells, you can’t cast them or concentrate on them while raging.

Your rage lasts for 1 minute. It ends early if you are knocked &Reference[unconscious]{unconscious} or if your turn ends and you haven’t attacked a hostile creature since your last turn or taken damage since then. You can also end your rage on your turn as a bonus action.

Once you have raged the number of times shown for your barbarian level in the Rages column of the Barbarian table, you must finish a long rest before you can rage again.

@UUID[Compendium.world.ddb-hoard-of-the-dragon-queen-ddb-classes.Item.P1De4xgoqXzyYbxM]{Level 1: Unarmored Defense}

While you are not wearing any armor, your Armor Class equals 10 + your Dexterity modifier + your Constitution modifier. You can use a shield and still gain this benefit.

@UUID[Compendium.world.ddb-hoard-of-the-dragon-queen-ddb-classes.Item.oPciqfz1dhiZFgjh]{Level 2: Reckless Attack}

Starting at 2nd level, you can throw aside all concern for defense to attack with fierce desperation. When you make your first attack on your turn, you can decide to attack recklessly. Doing so gives you advantage on melee weapon attack rolls using Strength during this turn, but attack rolls against you have advantage until your next turn.

@UUID[Compendium.world.ddb-hoard-of-the-dragon-queen-ddb-classes.Item.B008DQoefgYSozrJ]{Level 2: Danger Sense}

At 2nd level, you gain an uncanny sense of when things nearby aren’t as they should be, giving you an edge when you dodge away from danger.

You have advantage on Dexterity saving throws against effects that you can see, such as traps and spells. To gain this benefit, you can’t be &Reference[blinded]{blinded}, &Reference[deafened]{deafened}, or &Reference[incapacitated]{incapacitated}.

@UUID[Compendium.world.ddb-hoard-of-the-dragon-queen-ddb-classes.Item.2QvAtWri6vKe0e9f]{Level 3: Primal Path}

At 3rd level, you choose a path that shapes the &Reference[nat]{nature} of your rage. Your choice grants you features at 3rd level and again at 6th, 10th, and 14th levels.

Level 4: Ability Score Improvement

When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

@UUID[Compendium.world.ddb-hoard-of-the-dragon-queen-ddb-classes.Item.uTJ1TnaHbilzFuTR]{Level 5: Extra Attack}

Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

@UUID[Compendium.world.ddb-hoard-of-the-dragon-queen-ddb-classes.Item.S9lgLWRKAz3xGqTW]{Level 5: Fast Movement}

Starting at 5th level, your speed increases by 10 feet while you aren’t wearing heavy armor.

Level 7: Feral Instinct

By 7th level, your instincts are so honed that you have advantage on initiative rolls.

Additionally, if you are surprised at the beginning of combat and aren’t &Reference[incapacitated]{incapacitated}, you can act normally on your first turn, but only if you enter your rage before doing anything else on that turn.

Level 9: Brutal Critical

Beginning at 9th level, you can roll one additional weapon damage die when determining the extra damage for a critical hit with a melee attack.

This increases to two additional dice at 13th level and three additional dice at 17th level.

Level 11: Relentless Rage

Starting at 11th level, your rage can keep you fighting despite grievous wounds. If you drop to 0 hit points while you’re raging and don’t die outright, you can make a [[/save con 10 format=long]]. If you succeed, you drop to 1 hit point instead.

Each time you use this feature after the first, the DC increases by 5. When you finish a short or long rest, the DC resets to 10.

Level 15: Persistent Rage

Beginning at 15th level, your rage is so fierce that it ends early only if you fall &Reference[unconscious]{unconscious} or if you choose to end it.

Level 18: Indomitable Might

Beginning at 18th level, if your total for a [[/check str format=long]] is less than your Strength score, you can use that score in place of the total.

Level 20: Primal Champion

At 20th level, you embody the power of the wilds. Your Strength and Constitution scores increase by 4. Your maximum for those scores is now 24.

Starting Equipment

You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background:

  • (a) a greataxe or (b) any martial melee weapon
  • (a) two handaxes or (b) any simple weapon
  • An explorer’s pack and four javelins

Description

A fierce warrior who can enter a battle rage

Hit Die: d12
Primary Ability: Strength
Saves: Strength & Constitution 

Class Features

@UUID[Compendium.world.ddb-hoard-of-the-dragon-queen-ddb-classes.Item.GtlMziznYyJ6Zgdh]{Level 3: Spirit Seeker}

Yours is a path that seeks attunement with the natural world, giving you a kinship with beasts. At 3rd level when you adopt this path, you gain the ability to cast the beast sense and speak with animals spells, but only as rituals, as described in the Spellcasting section.

@UUID[Compendium.world.ddb-hoard-of-the-dragon-queen-ddb-classes.Item.kO8rH9HDlU6Jn3VW]{Level 3: Totem Spirit}

At 3rd level, when you adopt this path, you choose a totem spirit and gain its feature. You must make or acquire a physical totem object — an amulet or similar adornment — that incorporates fur or feathers, claws, teeth, or bones of the totem animal. At your option, you also gain minor physical attributes that are reminiscent of your totem spirit. For example, if you have a bear totem spirit, you might be unusually hairy and thick-skinned, or if your totem is the eagle, your eyes turn bright yellow.

Your totem animal might be an animal related to those listed here but more appropriate to your homeland. For example, you could choose a hawk or vulture in place of an eagle.

Level 6: Aspect of the Beast

At 6th level, you gain a magical benefit based on the totem animal of your choice. You can choose the same animal you selected at 3rd level or a different one.

Level 10: Spirit Walker

At 10th level, you can cast the commune with &Reference[nat]{nature} spell, but only as a ritual. When you do so, a spiritual version of one of the animals you chose for Totem Spirit or Aspect of the Beast appears to you to convey the information you seek.

Level 14: Totemic Attunement

At 14th level, you gain a magical benefit based on a totem animal of your choice. You can choose the same animal you selected previously or a different one.
+1 AC while wearing no armor Can touch a wall or floor and create a sticky web in 10ft DC 15 STR or be restrained for 1 minute

A cloth or leather pouch can hold 1/5 cubic foot/ 6 pounds of gear - or up to 20 sling bullets or 50 blowgun needles, among other things. A compartmentalized pouch for holding spell components is called a component pouch.
Nicki diamond loot

effects.name: Potion of Climbing - Consumable Effects
effects.description:
When you drink this potion, you gain a Climb Speed equal to your Speed for 1 hour. During this time, you have Advantage on Strength (&Reference[ath]{Athletics}) checks to climb.

This potion is separated into brown, silver, and gray layers resembling bands of stone. Shaking the bottle fails to mix the colors.

description.value:
When you drink this potion, you gain a Climb Speed equal to your Speed for 1 hour. During this time, you have Advantage on Strength (&Reference[ath]{Athletics}) checks to climb.

This potion is separated into brown, silver, and gray layers resembling bands of stone. Shaking the bottle fails to mix the colors.

When you drink this potion, you gain 10 Temporary Hit Points that last for 1 hour. For the same duration, you are under the effect of the Bless spell (no Concentration required).

This potion’s blue liquid bubbles and steams as if boiling.

You regain 4d4 + 4 Hit Points when you drink this potion.

Whatever its potency, the potion’s red liquid glimmers when agitated.

After drinking this potion, you can take a Bonus Action to exhale fire at a target within 30 feet of yourself. The target makes a [[/save dex 13 format=long]], taking [[/damage 4d6 type=fire average=true]] damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one. The effect ends after you exhale the fire three times or when 1 hour has passed.

This potion’s orange liquid flickers, and smoke fills the top of the container and wafts out whenever it is opened.
Grants advantage on saving throws against poison for 1 hour (75gp)
Resistance to non-magical bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing for 1 hour
Move up down and across vertical surfaces for 1 hour (75gp)
A character who drinks the magical red fluid in this vial regains [[/damage 2d4 + 2 type=heal average=false]] hit points. Drinking or administering a potion takes an action.
A character who drinks the magical red fluid in this vial regains [[/damage 2d4 + 2 type=heal average=false]] hit points. Drinking or administering a potion takes an action.

You've learned to put the weight of a weapon to your advantage, letting its momentum empower your strikes. You gain the following benefits:

  • On your turn, when you score a critical hit with a melee weapon or reduce a creature to 0 hit points with one, you can make one melee weapon attack as a bonus action.
  • Before you make a melee attack with a heavy weapon that you are proficient with, you can choose to take a -5 penalty to the attack roll. If the attack hits, you add +10 to the attack's damage.

Implementation Details

An effect is provided that can be toggled to enable or disable the Melee Weapon attack penalty and damage bonus.
description.chat:
On your turn, when you score a critical hit with a melee weapon or reduce a creature to 0 HP with one, you can make one melee weapon attack as a bonus action. Before you make a melee attack with a heavy weapon that you are proficient with, you can choose to take a -5 penalty to the attack roll to add +10 to the attack's damage.

Implementation Details

An effect is provided that can be toggled to enable or disable the Melee Weapon attack penalty and damage bonus.

description.value:
Instead of using a weapon to make a melee attack, you can use a punch, kick, head-butt, or similar forceful blow. In game terms, this is an Unarmed Strike—a melee attack that involves you using your body to damage, grapple, or shove a target within 5 feet of you.

Whenever you use your Unarmed Strike, choose one of the following options for its effect.

Damage. You make an attack roll against the target. Your bonus to the roll equals your Strength modifier plus your Proficiency Bonus. On a hit, the target takes Bludgeoning damage equal to 1 plus your Strength modifier.

Grapple. The target must succeed on a Strength or [[/save dex format=long]] (it chooses which), or it has the &Reference[grappled]{Grappled} condition. The DC for the saving throw and any escape attempts equals 8 plus your Strength modifier and Proficiency Bonus. This grapple is possible only if the target is no more than one size larger than you and if you have a hand free to grab it.

Shove. The target must succeed on a Strength or [[/save dex format=long]] (it chooses which), or you either push it 5 feet away or cause it to have the &Reference[prone]{Prone} condition. The DC for the saving throw equals 8 plus your Strength modifier and Proficiency Bonus. This shove is possible only if the target is no more than one size larger than you.
description.chat: You make a melee attack that involves using your body to deal one of the following effects: Damage. You make an attack roll against the creature, and on a hit, you deal 1 + STR Bludgeoning damage. Grapple. The target must succeed on a Str./Dex. (it chooses which) saving throw (DC = 8 + Prof. Bonus + Str.) or it has the &Reference[grappled]{Grappled} condition. Shove. The target must succeed on a Str./Dex. (it chooses which) saving throw (DC = 8 + Prof. Bonus + Str.) or you can either push it 5 ft. away or cause it to have the &Reference[prone]{Prone} condition.

description.value:
This bag has an interior space considerably larger than its outside dimensions, roughly 2 feet in diameter at the mouth and 4 feet deep. The bag can hold up to 500 pounds, not exceeding a volume of 64 cubic feet. The bag weighs 15 pounds, regardless of its contents. Retrieving an item from the bag requires an action.

If the bag is overloaded, pierced, or torn, it ruptures and is destroyed, and its contents are scattered in the Astral Plane. If the bag is turned inside out, its contents spill forth, unharmed, but the bag must be put right before it can be used again. Breathing creatures inside the bag can survive up to a number of minutes equal to 10 divided by the number of creatures (minimum 1 minute), after which time they begin to suffocate.

Placing a bag of holding inside an extradimensional space created by a handy haversack, portable hole, or similar item instantly destroys both items and opens a gate to the Astral Plane. The gate originates where the one item was placed inside the other. Any creature within 10 feet of the gate is sucked through it to a random location on the Astral Plane. The gate then closes. The gate is one-way only and can’t be reopened.

+1 Acrobatics JUMP - When you make a high jump, you leap into the air a number of feet equal to 3 + your Strength modifier if you move at least 10 feet on foot immediately before the jump. When you make a standing high jump, you can jump only half that distance.
Cyanwrath’s sword hand
Bell that rings super loud.
Mug that will always point towards the nearest tavern

items.name: Sharpened Battleaxe Blessed by the Copper Dragon

description.value:
Proficiency with a Battleaxe allows you to add your proficiency bonus to the attack roll for any attack you make with it.

This weapon has the following mastery property. To use this property, you must have a feature that lets you use it.

Topple. If you hit a creature with this weapon, you can force the creature to make a [[/save con format=long]] (DC 8 plus the ability modifier used to make the attack roll and your Proficiency Bonus). On a failed save, the creature has the &Reference[prone]{Prone} condition.

Proficiency with a Battleaxe allows you to add your proficiency bonus to the attack roll for any attack you make with it.

This weapon has the following mastery property. To use this property, you must have a feature that lets you use it.

Topple. If you hit a creature with this weapon, you can force the creature to make a [[/save con format=long]] (DC 8 plus the ability modifier used to make the attack roll and your Proficiency Bonus). On a failed save, the creature has the &Reference[prone]{Prone} condition.

Proficiency with a Scimitar allows you to add your proficiency bonus to the attack roll for any attack you make with it.

This weapon has the following mastery property. To use this property, you must have a feature that lets you use it.

Nick. When you make the extra attack of the Light property, you can make it as part of the Attack action instead of as a Bonus Action. You can make this extra attack only once per turn.

Proficiency with a Scimitar allows you to add your proficiency bonus to the attack roll for any attack you make with it.

This weapon has the following mastery property. To use this property, you must have a feature that lets you use it.

Nick. When you make the extra attack of the Light property, you can make it as part of the Attack action instead of as a Bonus Action. You can make this extra attack only once per turn.

Proficiency with a net allows you to add your proficiency bonus to the attack roll for any attack you make with it.

A Large or smaller creature hit by a net is &Reference[restrained]{restrained} until it is freed. A net has no effect on creatures that are formless, or creatures that are Huge or larger. A creature can use its action to make a [[/check str 10 format=long]], freeing itself or another creature within its reach on a success. Dealing 5 slashing damage to the net (AC 10) also frees the creature without harming it, ending the effect and destroying the net.

When you use an action, bonus action, or reaction to attack with a net, you can make only one attack regardless of the number of attacks you can normally make.

A backpack is a leather pack carried on the back, typically with straps to secure it. A backpack can hold 1 cubic foot/ 30 pounds of gear.

You can also strap items, such as a bedroll or a coil of rope, to the outside of a backpack.

A backpack is a leather pack carried on the back, typically with straps to secure it. A backpack can hold 1 cubic foot/ 30 pounds of gear.

You can also strap items, such as a bedroll or a coil of rope, to the outside of a backpack.
This set of clothes could consist of a loose shirt and baggy breeches, or a loose shirt and skirt or overdress. Cloth wrappings are used for shoes.
This set of clothes is fashioned after a particular costume, typically meant for entertaining.
A barrel can hold 40 gallons of liquid, or 4 cubic feet of solid material.
A bucket can hold 3 gallons of liquid, or 1/2 cubic foot of solid material.

A cloth or leather pouch can hold 1/5 cubic foot/ 6 pounds of gear - or up to 20 sling bullets or 50 blowgun needles, among other things. A compartmentalized pouch for holding spell components is called a component pouch.
A sack can hold 1 cubic foot/ 30 pounds of gear.
If you have proficiency with a certain kind of vehicle (land or water), you can add your proficiency bonus to any check you make to control that kind of vehicle in difficult circumstances.
Calms the user

This kit is a leather pouch containing bandages, salves, and splints. The kit has ten uses. As an action, you can expend one use of the kit to stabilize a creature that has 0 hit points, without needing to make a Wisdom (&Reference[med]{Medicine}) check.
Rations consist of dry foods suitable for extended travel, including jerky, dried fruit, hardtack, and nuts.
Rope, has 2 hit points and can be burst with a [[/check str 17 format=long]].
A waterskin can hold 4 pints of liquid.
A set of pulleys with a cable threaded through them and a hook to attach to objects, a block and tackle allows you to hoist up to four times the weight you can normally lift.
Using a crowbar grants advantage to Strength checks where the crowbar's leverage can be applied.

This kit is a leather pouch containing bandages, salves, and splints. The kit has ten uses. As an action, you can expend one use of the kit to stabilize a creature that has 0 hit points, without needing to make a Wisdom (&Reference[med]{Medicine}) check.

These metal restraints can bind a Small or Medium creature. Escaping the manacles requires a successful [[/check dex 20 format=long]]. Breaking them requires a successful [[/check str 20 format=long]]. Each set of manacles comes with one key. Without the key, a creature proficient with thieves' tools can pick the manacles' lock with a successful [[/check dex 15 format=long]]. Manacles have 15 hit points.

Oil usually comes in a clay flask that holds 1 pint. As an action, you can splash the oil in this flask onto a creature within 5 feet of you or throw it up to 20 feet, shattering it on impact. Make a ranged attack against a target creature or object, treating the oil as an improvised weapon. On a hit, the target is covered in oil. If the target takes any fire damage before the oil dries (after 1 minute), the target takes an additional 5 fire damage from the burning oil. You can also pour a flask of oil on the ground to cover a 5-foot-square area, provided that the surface is level. If lit, the oil burns for 2 rounds and deals 5 fire damage to any creature that enters the area or ends its turn in the area. A creature can take this damage only once per turn.
Rations consist of dry foods suitable for extended travel, including jerky, dried fruit, hardtack, and nuts.
Rope, has 2 hit points and can be burst with a [[/check str 17 format=long]].
A torch burns for 1 hour, providing bright light in a 20-foot radius and dim light for an additional 20 feet. If you make a melee attack with a burning torch and hit, it deals 1 fire damage.
Map of what Sean has drawn.
A standard bell that rings, typically used for signaling.
For 1 hour, a candle sheds bright light in a 5-foot radius and dim light for an additional 5 feet.
A piece of chalk used for writing and marking on various surfaces.
This tin box contains a cup and simple cutlery. The box clamps together, and one side can be used as a cooking pan and the other as a plate or shallow bowl.

A steel mirror is handy when you want to look around corners, signal friends with reflected sunlight, keep an eye on a medusa, make sure that you look good enough to present yourself to the queen, or examine wounds that you’ve received on hard-to-see parts of your body.

Oil usually comes in a clay flask that holds 1 pint. As an action, you can splash the oil in this flask onto a creature within 5 feet of you or throw it up to 20 feet, shattering it on impact. Make a ranged attack against a target creature or object, treating the oil as an improvised weapon. On a hit, the target is covered in oil. If the target takes any fire damage before the oil dries (after 1 minute), the target takes an additional 5 fire damage from the burning oil. You can also pour a flask of oil on the ground to cover a 5-foot-square area, provided that the surface is level. If lit, the oil burns for 2 rounds and deals 5 fire damage to any creature that enters the area or ends its turn in the area. A creature can take this damage only once per turn.
A small whistle used for signaling.
A commodity used for bathing.

This small container holds flint, fire steel, and tinder (usually dry cloth soaked in light oil) used to kindle a fire. Using it to light a torch -- or anything else with abundant, exposed fuel -- takes an action. Lighting any other fire takes 1 minute.
A torch burns for 1 hour, providing bright light in a 20-foot radius and dim light for an additional 20 feet. If you make a melee attack with a burning torch and hit, it deals 1 fire damage.
A standard whetstone used to sharpen blades.
A 10-foot length of string, typically found in a burglar's pack.

effects.name: Potion of Climbing - Consumable Effects
effects.description:
When you drink this potion, you gain a Climb Speed equal to your Speed for 1 hour. During this time, you have Advantage on Strength (&Reference[ath]{Athletics}) checks to climb.

This potion is separated into brown, silver, and gray layers resembling bands of stone. Shaking the bottle fails to mix the colors.

description.value:
When you drink this potion, you gain a Climb Speed equal to your Speed for 1 hour. During this time, you have Advantage on Strength (&Reference[ath]{Athletics}) checks to climb.

This potion is separated into brown, silver, and gray layers resembling bands of stone. Shaking the bottle fails to mix the colors.
You can breathe underwater for 1 hour after drinking this potion. Its cloudy green fluid smells of the sea and has a jellyfish-like bubble floating in it.

You regain 4d4 + 4 Hit Points when you drink this potion.

Whatever its potency, the potion’s red liquid glimmers when agitated.
A character who drinks the magical red fluid in this vial regains [[/damage 2d4 + 2 type=heal average=false]] hit points. Drinking or administering a potion takes an action.

You never know where you’re going to sleep, and a bedroll helps you get better sleep in a hayloft or on the cold ground. A bedroll consists of bedding and a blanket thin enough to be rolled up and tied. In an emergency, it can double as a stretcher.

A climber's kit includes special pitons, boot tips, gloves, and a harness. You can use the climber's kit as an action to anchor yourself; when you do, you can't fall more than 25 feet from the point where you anchored yourself, and you can't climb more than 25 feet away from that point without undoing the anchor.
This one-handed hammer with an iron head is useful for pounding pitons into a wall.
An iron pot can hold 1 gallon of liquid.
A simple and portable canvas shelter, a tent sleeps two.
A standard shovel used for digging.
A character who drinks the magical red fluid in this vial regains [[/damage 2d4 + 2 type=heal average=false]] hit points. Drinking or administering a potion takes an action.
A miner's pick is designed to concentrate the force of its blow on a small area.
Stuff for excavating?

You touch a willing beast. For the duration of the spell, you can use your action to see through the beast’s eyes and hear what it hears, and continue to do so until you use your action to return to your normal senses. While perceiving through the beast’s senses, you gain the benefits of any special senses possessed by that creature, though you are &Reference[blinded]{blinded} and &Reference[deafened]{deafened} to your own surroundings.

You gain the ability to comprehend and verbally communicate with beasts for the duration. The knowledge and awareness of many beasts is limited by their intelligence, but at minimum, beasts can give you information about nearby locations and monsters, including whatever they can perceive or have perceived within the past day. You might be able to persuade a beast to perform a small favor for you, at the GM's discretion.

You bless up to three creatures of your choice within range. Whenever a target makes an attack roll or a saving throw before the spell ends, the target can roll a d4 and add the number rolled to the attack roll or saving throw.

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, you can target one additional creature for each slot level above 1st.
At 3rd level, you choose a path that shapes the &Reference[nat]{nature} of your rage. Your choice grants you features at 3rd level and again at 6th, 10th, and 14th levels.

At 2nd level, you gain an uncanny sense of when things nearby aren’t as they should be, giving you an edge when you dodge away from danger.

You have advantage on Dexterity saving throws against effects that you can see, such as traps and spells. To gain this benefit, you can’t be &Reference[blinded]{blinded}, &Reference[deafened]{deafened}, or &Reference[incapacitated]{incapacitated}.
description.chat: You have advantage on DEX saving throws against effects that you can see while not &Reference[blinded]{blinded}, &Reference[deafened]{deafened}, or &Reference[incapacitated]{incapacitated}.

description.value: Yours is a path that seeks attunement with the natural world, giving you a kinship with beasts. At 3rd level when you adopt this path, you gain the ability to cast the beast sense and speak with animals spells, but only as rituals, as described in the Spellcasting section.
description.chat: You can cast beast sense and speak with animals as rituals.

effects.name: Unarmored Defense
effects.description: While not wearing armor, your AC equals 10 + DEX modifier + CON modifier + any shield bonus.

description.value: While you are not wearing any armor, your Armor Class equals 10 + your Dexterity modifier + your Constitution modifier. You can use a shield and still gain this benefit.
description.chat: While not wearing armor, your AC equals 10 + DEX modifier + CON modifier + any shield bonus.

effects.name: Fast Movement
effects.description: Your speed increases by 10 ft. while you aren't wearing heavy armor.

description.value: Starting at 5th level, your speed increases by 10 feet while you aren’t wearing heavy armor.
description.chat: Your speed increases by 10 ft. while you aren't wearing heavy armor.

description.value: Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.
description.chat: You can attack twice whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

description.value:
At 3rd level, when you adopt this path, you choose a totem spirit and gain its feature. You must make or acquire a physical totem object — an amulet or similar adornment — that incorporates fur or feathers, claws, teeth, or bones of the totem animal. At your option, you also gain minor physical attributes that are reminiscent of your totem spirit. For example, if you have a bear totem spirit, you might be unusually hairy and thick-skinned, or if your totem is the eagle, your eyes turn bright yellow.

Your totem animal might be an animal related to those listed here but more appropriate to your homeland. For example, you could choose a hawk or vulture in place of an eagle.

Bear

While raging, you have resistance to all damage except psychic damage. The spirit of the bear makes you tough enough to stand up to any punishment.

Eagle

While you’re raging, other creatures have disadvantage on opportunity attack rolls against you, and you can use the Dash action as a bonus action on your turn. The spirit of the eagle makes you into a predator who can weave through the fray with ease.

Elk

While you are raging and aren't wearing heavy armor, your walking speed increases by 15 feet. The spirit of the elk makes you extraordinarily swift.

Tiger

While raging, you can add 10 feet to your long jump distance and 3 feet to your high jump distance. The spirit of the tiger empowers your leaps.

Wolf

While you’re raging, your friends have advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature within 5 feet of you that is hostile to you. The spirit of the wolf makes you a leader of hunters.
description.chat: You have adopted a totem spirit.

description.value: Starting at 2nd level, you can throw aside all concern for defense to attack with fierce desperation. When you make your first attack on your turn, you can decide to attack recklessly. Doing so gives you advantage on melee weapon attack rolls using Strength during this turn, but attack rolls against you have advantage until your next turn.
description.chat: When you make your first attack on your turn, you can decide to attack recklessly, giving you advantage on melee weapon attack rolls using STR during this turn, but attack rolls against you have advantage until your next turn.

description.value: Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.
description.chat: You can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

description.value:
In battle, you fight with primal ferocity. On your turn, you can enter a rage as a bonus action.

While raging, you gain the following benefits if you aren’t wearing heavy armor:

  • You have advantage on Strength checks and Strength saving throws.
  • When you make a melee weapon attack using Strength, you gain a bonus to the damage roll that increases as you gain levels as a barbarian, as shown in the Rage Damage column of the Barbarian table.
  • You have resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage.

If you are able to cast spells, you can’t cast them or concentrate on them while raging.

Your rage lasts for 1 minute. It ends early if you are knocked &Reference[unconscious]{unconscious} or if your turn ends and you haven’t attacked a hostile creature since your last turn or taken damage since then. You can also end your rage on your turn as a bonus action.

Once you have raged the number of times shown for your barbarian level in the Rages column of the Barbarian table, you must finish a long rest before you can rage again.
description.chat: As a bonus action enter a rage for up to 1 minute (10 rounds). You gain advantage on STR checks and saving throws (not attacks), [[/roll @scale.barbarian.rage]] melee damage with STR weapons, resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, slashing damage. You can't cast or concentrate on spells while raging. Your rage ends early if you are knocked &Reference[unconscious]{unconscious} or if your turn ends and you haven’t attacked a hostile creature since your last turn or taken damage since then. You can also end your rage as a bonus action.

description.value:
At 6th level, you gain a magical benefit based on the totem animal of your choice. You can choose the same animal you selected at 3rd level or a different one.

Bear

You gain the might of a bear. Your carrying capacity (including maximum load and maximum lift) is doubled, and you have advantage on Strength checks made to push, pull, lift, or break objects.

Eagle

You gain the eyesight of an eagle. You can see up to 1 mile away with no difficulty, able to discern even fine details as though looking at something no more than 100 feet away from you. Additionally, dim light doesn’t impose disadvantage on your Wisdom (Perception) checks.

Elk

Whether mounted or on foot, your travel pace is doubled, as is the travel pace of up to ten companions while they’re within 60 feet of you and you’re not &Reference[incapacitated]{incapacitated} (see “Adventuring,” for rules on travel pace). The elk spirit helps you roam far and fast.

Tiger

You gain proficiency in two skills from the following list: &Reference[ath]{Athletics}, &Reference[acr]{Acrobatics}, &Reference[ste]{Stealth}, and &Reference[sur]{Survival}. The cat spirit hones your &Reference[sur]{survival} instincts.

Wolf

You gain the hunting sensibilities of a wolf. You can track other creatures while traveling at a fast pace, and you can move stealthily while traveling at a normal pace (see “Adventuring,” for rules on travel pace).
description.chat: You gain a magical benefit based on the totem animal of your choice.

description.value: At 3rd level, you choose a path that shapes the &Reference[nat]{nature} of your rage. Your choice grants you features at 3rd level and again at 6th, 10th, and 14th levels.

At 2nd level, you gain an uncanny sense of when things nearby aren’t as they should be, giving you an edge when you dodge away from danger.

You have advantage on Dexterity saving throws against effects that you can see, such as traps and spells. To gain this benefit, you can’t be &Reference[blinded]{blinded}, &Reference[deafened]{deafened}, or &Reference[incapacitated]{incapacitated}.

description.chat: You gain a magical benefit based on the totem animal of your choice.

description.value: When you are reduced to 0 hit points but not killed outright, you can drop to 1 hit point instead. You can’t use this feature again until you finish a long rest.
description.chat: When you are reduced to 0 HP but not killed, you can drop to 1 HP instead once per long rest.

description.value: You gain proficiency in the &Reference[itm]{Intimidation} skill.
When you score a critical hit with a melee weapon attack, you can roll one of the weapon’s damage dice one additional time and add it to the extra damage of the critical hit.
description.chat: When you score a critical hit, roll one of the weapon’s dice one additional time and add it to the extra damage.

description.value:
Some half-orcs rise to become proud leaders of orc communities. Some venture into the world to prove their worth. Many of these become adventurers, achieving greatness for their mighty deeds.

Racial Traits
+2 Strength, +1 Constitution, &Reference[darkvision]{Darkvision}, Menacing, Relentless Endurance, Savage Attacks

&Reference[darkvision]{Darkvision}

Thanks to your orc blood, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can’t discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

Menacing

You gain proficiency in the &Reference[itm]{Intimidation} skill.

Relentless Endurance

When you are reduced to 0 hit points but not killed outright, you can drop to 1 hit point instead. You can’t use this feature again until you finish a long rest.

Savage Attacks

When you score a critical hit with a melee weapon attack, you can roll one of the weapon’s damage dice one additional time and add it to the extra damage of the critical hit.

Ability Score Increase

Your Strength score increases by 2, and your Constitution score increases by 1.

Languages

You can speak, read, and write Common and Orc. Orc is a harsh, grating language with hard consonants. It has no script of its own but is written in the Dwarvish script.

Age

Half-orcs mature a little faster than humans, reaching adulthood around age 14. They age noticeably faster and rarely live longer than 75 years.

Size

Half-orcs are somewhat larger and bulkier than humans, and they range from 5 to well over 6 feet tall. Your size is Medium.

Speed

Your base walking speed is 30 feet.
When you are reduced to 0 hit points but not killed outright, you can drop to 1 hit point instead. You can’t use this feature again until you finish a long rest.
description.chat: When you are reduced to 0 HP but not killed, you can drop to 1 HP instead once per long rest.

description.value: You gain proficiency in the &Reference[itm]{Intimidation} skill.
When you score a critical hit with a melee weapon attack, you can roll one of the weapon’s damage dice one additional time and add it to the extra damage of the critical hit.
description.chat: When you score a critical hit, roll one of the weapon’s dice one additional time and add it to the extra damage.

description.value:

Racial Traits

&Reference[darkvision]{Darkvision}

Thanks to your orc blood, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can’t discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

Menacing

Relentless Endurance

When you are reduced to 0 hit points but not killed outright, you can drop to 1 hit point instead. You can’t use this feature again until you finish a long rest.

Savage Attacks

When you score a critical hit with a melee weapon attack, you can roll one of the weapon’s damage dice one additional time and add it to the extra damage of the critical hit.

Ability Score Increase

Your Strength score increases by 2, and your Constitution score increases by 1.

Languages

You can speak, read, and write Common and Orc. Orc is a harsh, grating language with hard consonants. It has no script of its own but is written in the Dwarvish script.

Age

Half-orcs mature a little faster than humans, reaching adulthood around age 14. They age noticeably faster and rarely live longer than 75 years.

Size

Half-orcs are somewhat larger and bulkier than humans, and they range from 5 to well over 6 feet tall. Your size is Medium.

Speed

Your base walking speed is 30 feet.

Background: Orc Outcast

Getting beat up by orcs much larger has caused the character to have increased &Reference[prc]{perception}. Until that &Reference[prc]{perception} gets built up, better put a bandage with ointment on those boo boos.
